config.content: Register and login. To add your own information to the map you must register using your Facebook or Google details, or else by providing an email address and password.  After registering, add information about yourself using the ‘Edit your profile’ link at the top of the page. You can decide what information about yourself you make available to other users with the ’Sharing and searching options’ link.
Access Frequently Asked Questions about how to use the website and a description of the project from these menu items.
Adoptee profile tab. When you are looking at the profile of adoptees, their birth stories, contact details and story cards appear in this window.

Understanding the scale of adoptions. Clicking on this button shows the number of adoptees coming from each of Canada’s provinces and where the adoptees were first moved. By clicking on the coloured buttons that appear when you hover over this button, you can filter the provinces that you want to appear on the map.

The Storyline. This is used to add information about the different locations that you have lived in. Each location is a unique ‘card’. To add a card click on the ‘Add more locations along your story’ card at the bottom of the map.  The Storyline is also used to view and access the cards of other adoptees that you are searching for. Matching search results appear in the storyline. When you click on individual cards, detailed information will appear in the profile tab and the location will be displayed on the map.

config.text:
Important Information and Disclaimer

 In our Own Words Mapping the 60s Scoop Survivor Diaspora

The 60s Scoop is a catch all phrase which describes an era from 1950’s to early 1980’s where over 20,000 Indigenous children were removed from their communities and placed in foster care or adopted into non-Indigenous households across Canada, the U.S and overseas. Most of the children were often assimilated into mainstream culture which resulted in loss of culture and identity and in some cases traumatic abuses. Many survivors are still learning about the 60s scoop, their displacement, looking for family members, healing from trauma, grief and loss of culture.

The Sixties Scoop Network formerly known as the National Indigenous Survivors of Child Welfare Network aka is collaborating with Dr. Raven Sinclair’s Pe-kīwēwin Project to create a Geographic Information Mapping platform to help 60’s scoop survivors share their stories, visualize their geographical displacements and to collect data on where survivors were taken from and subsequently displaced. This visualization of the data will take the form of a map. In addition, the project will assist in finding family members and identifying resources in different areas.

The mapping project is completely voluntary and participatory. Survivors can directly input their own information into the online mapping system and have the option to share as little or as much information about themselves as they want, as well as short videos, pictures and a short narrative about themselves. If survivors choose to locate family members, they have the option of uploading a picture, file, short video or details on the person whom they are looking for and/or who may be looking for them. Participants will have the option of removing any of their identifying visual data from the platform at any time. However, anonymous statistical data on province/area of child welfare removal, First Nations, Metis, Inuit identity, adopted or not adopted will be to inform public knowledge. The Sixties Scoop Network will have access to the (platform’s data and 60’s scoop survivor users will have access to their own information.

The scope of this project is international because so many 60’s scoop survivors were displaced to the United States and overseas. The mapping project would be a useful tool for survivors in addition to providing researchers and indigenous communities a data visualization of how Canada’s colonial child welfare policies resulted in the displacement of thousands of Indigenous children from the 1950’s to 1990s. Moreover, this mapping project will enable researchers to produce statistical data and help identify which geographical areas indigenous children were taken from and where these children ended up by using a colour code for each province as a point of origin and identifying where survivors were subsequently fostered or adopted. For example, indigenous children taken from BC would be identified using red, Alberta, green, Saskatchewan yellow, Manitoba orange etc. Visually, it will be striking to see where all the survivors were taken across Canada, the U.S and overseas.

Lastly, this project aims to identify resources for 60s scoop survivors to find support and help in repatriating, cultural reclamation, counselling and locating other 60s scoop survivors’ groups across Canada. It is our hope to include resource information that can be accessible to survivors through our platform as survivors’ stories become available.

Disclaimer:

Keep in mind the information contained on the website https://sixtiesscoopnetwork.org/ is for general information purposes only. The Geographic Information In our Own Words: Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivors Diaspora project assumes no responsibility for errors or omissions pertaining to the contents on the information uploaded by individual users.

In no event, shall the Geographic Information In our Own Words: Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivors Diaspora project or team members be liable for any special, direct, indirect, consequential, or incidental damages or any damages whatsoever, whether in an action of contract, negligence or other tort, arising out of or in connection with the use of the service or the contents of the service. The Geographic Information n our Own Words Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivors Diaspora project reserves the right to make additions, deletions, or modification to the map and general information and/or harmful, criminal, objectionable content. This Disclaimer for Geographic Information In our Own Words: Mapping the Indigenous Survivors of Child Welfare Diaspora has been created with the help of TermsFeed.

Geographic Information In our Own Words: Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivors Diaspora does not warrant that the website is free of viruses or other harmful components.

External links disclaimer

https://sixtiesscoopnetwork.org/ website may contain links to external websites that are not provided or maintained by or in any way affiliated with GIS In our Own Words: Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivors Diaspora Please note that the GIS In our Own Words: Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivors Diaspora does not guarantee the accuracy, relevance, timeliness, or completeness of any information on these external websites.

*Diaspora “diaspora does not simply refer to geographical dispersal but also to the vexed questions of identity, memory and home which such displacement produces” (Ashcroft et al 1989, 218).

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

Getting started

We recommend that before using the site for the first time you click on the ‘Question mark’ button on the map. This will run you through a quick start tutorial on how to use the site link to tutorial. [The text for this tutorial is below]

How do I search for an adoptee?

If you click on the search icon (magnifying glass) on the right-hand side of the map, you will open a panel with a number of ways that you can search for adoptees. You can search by name, date of birth, location of birth or places that an adoptee lived during their Story. Type in all the details that you know then click the blue search button. Your search results will appear as a set of cards in the Storyline under the map. Click on any of the cards to access the information and view the information on the map.

How do I add my own information?

To add your own information to the map you will first need to register. To do this click on the register button link to register. You can register for the site using your Facebook or Google credentials, or else by providing an email address and password.

Once you have registered and are logged in you can add information about yourself using the ‘Edit your profile’ link at the top of the page. Once your profile is complete, you can decide how you want to make your information available to users of the site or members of the public by clicking on the ’Sharing and searching options’.

Now you are ready to add the different stages of your story. We have divided your story up by the locations that you have lived in. Each location requires a unique ‘card’. To add a card, click on the ‘Add more locations along your story’ card at the bottom of the map. Fill out the details and click save. Keep adding cards for each of the places that you have lived.

If you have been repatriated with your family click on the ‘Add a repatriation story’, fill out the details and click Finish.

Why can’t I sign in?

You might be unable to sign in because you have not registered to use the site. Please try to register first. If this does not work, please contact us directly and we will help resolve this issue.

How do I make my information available to other people?

Open the ’Sharing and searching options’ from the top of the page. You will be asked if you ‘Are you looking for your parents, siblings or family members?’ and whether you have any information about your birth family that you would share publicly? If you choose ‘Yes’ to either of these questions you will be asked to share the details that you know including name, birth date and place of residence.

You can also select whether you would like your information to be public and made available through this website and whether other users can see your email address and to contact you thought the site.

Can I create more than one story?

Currently you can only create one story with each adoptee profile.

What does the yellow star mean on adoptee profiles?

The yellow star means that this adoptee is actively looking for their parents, siblings or family members.

How do I edit and change the information in my story?

You can change information on individual cards directly from your Storyline. Hover your mouse over the card you want to change and click on the edit button that appears. You can change any information on the card, remember to save it!

How will my information be used, stored and is it secure?

Your information will be stored on Amazon Web Services servers located in Montreal. We take your data privacy very seriously and will do our utmost to ensure that your information is secure, and the system maintained. Your information will only be available to other users of the site if you select the option to share it.

Can I be contacted through the website?

You can only be contacted if you chose to share your details, for instance if you are looking for biological family members and want to be contacted you can indicate this in your profile. The only other person who may contact you is the administrator of the mapping site.

How many pictures can I upload?

At this time, it is best to upload just one picture per story card.

How long of a video can I share?

In order to share a video, it will need to be hosted on YouTube or Vimeo and then linked to your profile. Your video can be already existing, or you can create a new one and add it to YouTube or Vimeo.

In order to upload a video on YouTube or Vimeo, you will need to create an account first. Once your account is created, and you have uploaded your video – you can go to share button, select the video option and copy and paste the URL link into your profile.

How do I delete my information?

You can delete individual cards directly from your Storyline. Hover your mouse over the card you want to remove and click on red coloured delete button that appears. You will be asked if you really want to delete the card.

How much do I pay to use this web mapping tool?

There are no fees to use this mapping site, but donations are gratefully accepted to help maintain the security and maintenance of hosting the website.

No government funding was used to create this project, small grants from Firelight Social Return Fund and Waakebiness-Bryce Institute for Indigenous Health Dalla Lana School of Public Health, University of Toronto

This is a grassroots project by survivors for survivors to provide a real time platform to share our stories, visualize our displacements and eventually identify resources for healing, cultural reclamation and repatriation.

Can I edit or delete someone else’s information?

No, you can only edit and add information about your own story.

Who do I contact if I have questions?

If you have any questions about the site or information displayed on it, please contact us directly contact email.

Why can’t I see someone’s information?

You might not be able to view someone’s information because they are not on the system, they have not added their information to the map, or else they want the information to remain private.

Does this tool work on my phone?

We are currently trying to make the site compatible with mobile phones. There are some challenges with this we will keep you posted.

How do I report a problem?

If you have any questions about the technical side of the website site, please contact us directly support email.

Acknowledgements

This project evolved from a simple drawing on a piece of paper. The process of taking that drawing to an interactive GIS platform online has been a labour of love. The idea behind the drawing was to show the displacement and trafficking of First Nation, Metis and Inuit children through Canada’s child welfare system inter-provincially, across borders and overseas by using visual markers, colours, lines and a map.

I introduced my idea to Dr. Raven Sinclair in 2014 showing her what I envisioned the map to look like on a global digital online platform. As Indigenous folks, we are visual learners and we instinctively knew that if the data could be displayed visually, it could have an impact on survivors and the general public. A visual depiction of the removal of a generation of Indigenous children from their families, communities, traditional homelands, would have an impact far beyond reading an article or listening to a podcast could have.

Raven got the idea right away and has been a champion of this project since the beginning. Steve Deroy at the Firelight Group was the next champion and supporter of this project. Raven’s SSHRC Insight Grant provided support for me to participate in three annual Indigenous Mapping Workshops which helped me learn about GIS (geographical information system) and meet other Indigenous folks worldwide doing amazing work with GIS mapping platforms. It was through the Indigenous Mapping Workshops that I eventually met Dr. Jon Corbett and Nick Black who took on the enormous task of creating an interactive GIS mapping platform that would allow us to share our stories, show our displacements and find family members. This is the first of its kind; there is no other online interactive platform for 60s scoop survivors to participate in, share their stories through pictures and videos and to potentially locate family. It has taken years and piecemeal funding from multiple sources to get to this point where we can introduce this project In our own Words: Mapping the Stories of 60s Scoop Survivor Diaspora

I would like to extend many thanks to the sponsors who donated money to this project and believed and knew the importance of getting our stories out there and bringing the 60s scoop to the forefront of human rights issues. Understanding the context of current Indigenous issues and how Indigenous child removals in Canada impacted generations of families left to grieve, mourn their losses but also the children of 60s scoop survivors who are intergenerationally impacted and are now the millennial scoop and youth growing up without connection to culture and family.

To move forward, we collectively need to heal, learn what happened and break the cycle.

The Firelight Group Social Return Fund

Waakebiness-Bryce Institute for Indigenous Health, University of Toronto

Pe-kiwewin Research project, Dr. Raven Sinclair, PI, Social Science and Humanities Research Council of Canada

CUPE Canadian Union of Public Employees

PSAC – Public Service Alliance of Canada

Criminology Dept at Carleton University

Special thanks to Dr. Jon Corbett and Nick Black at Geoforms for their hard work and dedication to this project, Dr. Raven Sinclair

for her unwavering support and friendship, Denali Youngwolfe, Steve Deroy & folks at the Firelight Group, Micheall Desautel, Dana Wesley, Natasha Sterritt, Dr. Jeff Managhan, friends and family who have continually supported the project from day 1. Thank you,

Colleen Hele Cardinal
View this story on the map
